message.content:
cs.NI, cs.CR, cs.SI, cs.DC, cs.IT 

Reasoning: The paper focuses on the security of the Internet's routing infrastructure and the impact of BGP poisoning on systems built on top of the Internet. This suggests that the paper is likely to belong to the Networking and Internet Architecture (cs.NI) category. Additionally, the paper discusses the graph-theoretic aspects of available paths and the connectivity concerns when poisoning, which are relevant to the Distributed, Parallel, and Cluster Computing (cs.DC) and Security and Privacy (cs.CR) categories. The paper also presents predictive models for understanding an ASes' vulnerability to poisoning, which falls under the Information Theory (cs.IT) category. Finally, the paper uses real-world measurements to evaluate the feasibility of BGP poisoning, which is relevant to the Social and Information Networks (cs.SI) category.
